target_text: A man is seated at a table with some tools, where his upper arm is positioned moderately above shoulder level, increasing strain on the shoulder joint. His neck is side-bent, leading to muscle imbalance and fatigue, while his trunk is bent forward between 20 and 60 degrees, causing increased spinal loading. Furthermore, his lower arm appears too extended or overly flexed, which can result in fatigue if maintained for prolonged periods. Additionally, he is standing on one leg, creating an asymmetric load on the lower body.

A man is seated at a table working on a task. His lower arms are either too extended or overly flexed, a posture that can lead to muscle fatigue over time. Additionally, he is standing on one leg, introducing an asymmetric load to his lower body that may cause imbalance and discomfort. His neck is extended as he leans forward to focus on his work, increasing stress on the cervical spine.

A woman is seated at a desk in an office, engaged in her work. Her upper arm is held moderately above shoulder level, increasing strain on the shoulder joint. Her lower arms show postures that are either too extended or overly flexed, which can lead to muscular fatigue if sustained. She is also observed standing on one leg, creating an asymmetric load on the lower body. Additionally, her neck is extended, contributing to increased stress on the cervical spine.

A man is seen standing on a table in a room, performing overhead tasks. His upper arm is raised far above shoulder level and abducted, placing significant stress on the shoulder joint and increasing the risk of rotator cuff instability. Additionally, his trunk is rotated, which elevates torsional load on the spine and heightens the risk of back strain.

The scene depicts a room filled with boxes scattered across the floor. A man within the environment is bent forward between 20 and 60 degrees, a posture that notably increases spinal loading and can contribute to lower back strain over time.

In a cluttered room filled with boxes, a man is seen standing with his neck extended, a posture that increases stress on the cervical spine. In another scene, he is positioned in a doorway while his trunk bends forward between 20 and 60 degrees, contributing to increased spinal loading and potential lower back strain. Additionally, when kneeling among the boxes, he is observed standing on one leg, creating an asymmetric load that can lead to imbalance and discomfort.

A man is working on a table in a room, maintaining a posture where his trunk is bent forward between 20 and 60 degrees and rotated, significantly increasing torsional load on the spine and the risk of lower back fatigue. In the surrounding environment filled with boxes, he continues his tasks, sustaining these non-neutral postures that can exacerbate ergonomic strain.

While kneeling in a room, the man’s trunk is severely bent forward, placing him at high risk of lower back strain. At the same time, he is balancing his weight on one leg, introducing asymmetric loading on the lower body. In another scene, he stands on a skateboard, further challenging his balance and stability in an already cluttered space.

Seated at a desk working on a laptop, the man is observed with his trunk bent forward between 20 and 60 degrees. This posture increases spinal loading and places added strain on the lower back, highlighting the ergonomic risks associated with prolonged seated work without adequate support or posture correction.
A man is seated at a desk working on a laptop. His neck is extended, a posture that increases stress on the cervical spine and may lead to discomfort or fatigue if sustained over time.

A man is seated at a desk working on a laptop. His upper arms are positioned moderately above shoulder level, increasing strain on the shoulder joints. His lower arms are either too extended or overly flexed, which may lead to fatigue over time. His neck is extended, placing additional stress on the cervical spine, and he is also standing on one leg, introducing an asymmetric load on the lower body that could affect balance and posture.

Standing in front of a desk with a laptop, the man maintains a well-aligned and ergonomically neutral posture. His upper arms, lower arms, neck, trunk, and legs are all positioned within acceptable ranges, and no immediate ergonomic risks are identified.
While seated at a desk in front of a computer, the man’s trunk bends forward between 20 and 60 degrees, a posture known to increase spinal loading and elevate the risk of lower back strain over time.

A man is seated at a table working on something, with his lower arms either overly extended or flexed, posing a risk of muscle fatigue. His neck is side-bent, contributing to muscle imbalance and fatigue, while his trunk is bent forward between 20 and 60 degrees, increasing spinal loading. He is also standing on one leg, which introduces an asymmetric load on the lower body.

While seated at a table and working, the man's upper arm is positioned moderately above shoulder level, increasing strain on the shoulder joint. His trunk is also bent forward between 20 and 60 degrees, adding spinal loading and potential risk of lower back discomfort.

In an office setting, a man is seated with his upper arm held moderately above shoulder level, placing strain on the shoulder joint. His lower arms are either too extended or overly flexed, which may lead to fatigue, and his trunk is rotated, increasing torsional stress on the spine. In a separate scene, he sits at a table with his neck extended, placing additional load on the cervical spine. Finally, while seated at a desk with a laptop, he is observed standing on one leg, introducing an asymmetric load on the lower body.

A man is seen working at a table in a room. All observed body parts—including the upper arm, lower arm, neck, trunk, and legs—are in neutral and acceptable ergonomic conditions. No immediate interventions are necessary.

The scene shows a room filled with boxes on the floor. The individual present maintains an ergonomically sound posture—his upper arms, lower arms, neck, trunk, and legs are all in acceptable conditions, indicating no significant ergonomic risk.

In a room cluttered with boxes, a man is seen with his neck extended, a position that increases stress on the cervical spine. In another scene, he stands in a doorway with his trunk bent forward between 20 and 60 degrees, a posture that significantly raises spinal loading. Later, while kneeling and working on a machine, he is observed standing on one leg, resulting in asymmetric loading on the lower body and potential imbalance.

While working on a table in a room, the man’s trunk is bent forward between 20 and 60 degrees. This posture increases spinal compression and may lead to lower back strain, especially if maintained for extended periods.

While kneeling in a room with boxes, the man’s trunk is severely bent forward, placing him at high risk of lower back strain. He is also seen standing on one leg, creating an asymmetric load on the lower body. In another scene, he balances on a skateboard, further challenging his stability and postural control.

A man is seated at a desk with a laptop in front of him. His neck is extended, a posture that increases stress on the cervical spine and may lead to discomfort or fatigue during prolonged periods of computer use.

While seated at a desk using a laptop, the man’s trunk is bent forward between 20 and 60 degrees, increasing spinal loading and risk of lower back strain. He is also standing on one leg, introducing an asymmetric load to the lower body that can affect balance and cause additional strain over time.
